comments.text:
When I said that the old foundation of monetary economics needs to be torn 
down, I specifically pointed out that everyone would have to understand why 
first. Speculation about the future seems somewhat pointless when we as a 
society can't even reach any kind of concensus on what's not working in the 
present and why that is.

I am not trying to preach to anyone or pretend like I have all the answers. 
I don't and never will. All we can do as human beings is attempt to find 
what's true. I try to think about things as logically as possible, 
sometimes I make mistakes and years later look back in horror. :)

We have had a society based on scarcity and competition for the last two 
thousand years at least. We have had plenty of time to analyze the constant 
traits this differential system of advantage produces with absolute 
certainty.
1. War/Conflict.
2. Disease.

Logically, even in a pure libertarian utopia, it would exist upon a 
foundation of monetary economics, and would therefor encourage conflict, 
which creates disease. Likewise, a communist or socialist utopia would also 
be existant upon that same foundation of monetary economics, and thus have 
the same traits, conflict and disease.

When I say disease, I mean it in it's literal sense of dis-ease. The 
psychological effects on humans of conflict and competition is actually 
quite horrific.

In my personal opinion, political idealogy's and economic idealogy's are a 
kind of iteration of balance/control counterweights which attempt to 
improve the flawed foundation of monetary economics. Like trying to build a 
house on an unstable foundation, everything done is really just kicking the 
can down the road. Until everyone working on the project admits that they 
need to start over and understands what went wrong and why, the problems 
will continue.

comments.text:
Interesting. Is your and Benjamin's point that TED only attempts to inspire 
and engender corporate aggrandizement, presenting only the bright sides of  
technological innovation and advancement, appealing to idyllic emotionalism 
and whatever's currently in vogue (possibly put there by corporate 
propaganda), while neglecting to address the possible negative 
repurcussions of said exploration and advancement? If this is what TED 
does, then I would agree with both you and Benjamin. I am going to watch 
more TED talks and see more of what you are describing. I am also going to 
have to watch Benjamin's presentation again.
 
Your points raise some interesting quandaries.
 
One is whether anyone will watch anything that doesn't appeal to their 
emotionalism or their need to be inspired. We humans seem to be pretty 
simple in that regard.
 
Secondly, if TED allows the critiquing of creative innovation, will 
corporations shut them down? On Fox, would TED become the liberal agenda? 
On CNN, would TED become aloof and elitist scientists and/or denial 
advocates?
 
Thirdly, hindsight is 20/20... foresight is 0/0... I'm not so sure anyone 
will ever will be able, willing or daring enough to accurately explore and 
present the negatives. Valiant though their endeavors might be, anything 
they say will likely be, basically, ignored.
 
We humans seem to be built to go forward without too much thinking. We may 
be simply fated to suffer the unforeseen, unpredicable consequences of our 
foolish endeavors. (as long as those who profit from our foolish endeavors 
continue to push us to do so)
 
It seems that what we may now be learning is that technological evolution 
goes full circle... that all this wondrous innovation may actually be 
leading to societal, moral, ethical decay, environmental havoc, gross 
separation of rich and poor, and the innermost disquieting feelings that 
all is really NOT right with the world.
 
So what's the point of presenting the downsides if nobody will listen? 
Perhaps the point is, it's the right thing to do. And maybe we'll get it 
together and find a way to stop fueling our own demise.
comments.author: Girl of the Forest

comments.text:
The problem is that TED talks try to affirm that there is nothing is wrong 
with the world, that all problems can be solved without any significant 
change to society. Some of the talkers even say that corporations (like 
Nest or Duolingo) can be altruistic and help people.
We live in a world were work is more effective than ever. Thanks to 
technology, we need less work and energy than ever to produce food, water, 
clothing, housing etc. Never our cars, appliances and power plants been as 
efficient and "eco-friendly" as the ones produced today. Yet: we work more 
than ever, nearly half of the worlds population lives in poverty, and we 
are increasing our Co2 emissions every year. Technology & innovation, by 
itself, does NOT solve any problems.
The problem is rampant overconsumption that only benefits the richest. No 
tech solution or hot start-up can solve that problem. It is a problem that 
requires that we as a society all take a cold, hard look at how the world 
works and how we are doing things today. As Benjamin mentioned in his talk 
all TEDers seem to subscribe to the idealised version of capitalism, they 
don't necessarily live in the real world of applied capitalism.

''if you pause and think about what he's saying, you'll realize he's

It's not gibberish. Maybe it's hard to follow some references he's throwing 
at you, but his talk makes a lot of sense.

I don't know if I can simplify and convey it, but according to him (maybe 
I'm wrong or he's wrong) TED or society in general, believe that some guys 
coming up with ideas can just change the world. For example, a guy travels 
to India, sees the shit on streets and decides that people need to be set 
up with portable toilets and Indian sanitation problem (at least this 
aspect of it) will be solved. 
But then it turns out that this doesn't work, because Indian culture says 
that it's not right to sh** indoors on such a toilet, and when you're 
outdoors, nobody uses the toilets because they can just sh** on the street. 
It's not that they're dumb people, but their view of the world is 
different. And that's much harder to change than just give them some tech 
solution. 

The same with drones and automated manufacturing and new technologies... 
People think that actually IN CAPITALISM AT ITS CURRENT FORM we'll be 
better off with all that, but we won't be. They'll either 1) make us lazy 
and complacent 2) kick us out of our jobs. We need to tear down the old 
system, at least question it more, and I also don't know the magic formula, 
but whatever we have now will not help us to correctly distribute the 
benefits of information age to everyone. 

He said it correctly- when people on TED talks talk about something they 
have invented, they usually just brush past any cultural, politic, 
economic, social etc. implications of it. They just say ''well, it can be 
used both in good and bad way, but I'm sure we'll all be ok, because this

All the ideas and hard work won't help you, if society is not on the same

love to dream Utopian worlds, but as for me I could careless. I want 
solutions that work in the real world. Bitcoin as it is today, already 
solves all my problems, and if anyone takes the time to learn it a bit more 
(yes its complicated, get over it). Anything in life that is worth it, is 
worth reading over it. Sure it might be a huge stumbling block for many, no 
doubt. TCP/IP and the internet was difficult and hard to build the 
applications that never stopped anyone from using it. At the end of the 
day, something with real utility rarely gets the attention it should, while 
crappy stuff sold in a golden box is sold as revolutionary. Go figure... IN 
an effort to "think outside of the box" we are still thinking inside of 
that box. Its funny, but all those supposed innovation is more of the same 
junk. Did the internet succeed and changed the life of those who have 
access to the information. Yes, is the work over? No, but the point is that 
we will solve the problem, despite the con artists/TED pie in the sky 
talkers. We could solve it quicker, if the right people are compensated. 
Instead of wasting time energy, efforts, on a bunch of con artists selling 
pipe dreams.
comments.author: Jorge Armendariz

comments.text:
Fine, yes. It's in their mission statement that ideas have the power to 
change the world. You got me.

I don't hold TED on a pedestal, however, don't put words in my mouth. I 
called this talk out as being an idiotic and assholish rant not because I 
wish to defend TED but because the rant is idiotic and the ranter is an 
asshole. Apparently very few people can see the fallacies that saturate 
this talk, so allow me to enumerate them:

"Have you ever wondered why so little of the bright futures promised in TED 
talks actually come true?"

No. I haven't. You know why? Because I know that discussing ideas about how 
to change the world is very different to actually changing the world. I 
know that actually changing the world is a very difficult thing to do, so 
many of the ideas discussed will ultimately fail. I also know that many TED 
talks are not about promising a bright future. Some are about music, art 
and entertainment (you know, the 'E' in TED). Some are about discoveries. 
Some are about the problems we face. I also know that many past TED talks 
have actually come to fruition and changed the world.

"My TED talk is not about my work"

That's a great lie. His talk is almost word-for-word a recitation of an 
article he wrote called, "Why TED is a recipe for Civilizational Disaster". 
This talk is no different then when Malcolm Gladwell paraphrases what his 
latest book is about.

"The first problem is oversimplification. Now, to be clear I have nothing 
against the idea of interesting people who do smart things explaining their 
work in a way that everyone can understand"

Really? That's interesting because he then goes on to recite an anecdote 
where some idiot demands that an astrophysicist explain his work like 
Malcolm Gladwell, but instead of slamming that particular individual as 
being one of the many idiots that inhabit this planet, he slams Malcolm 
Gladwell who's very job description is "explain the work of interesting 
people who do smart things in a way that everyone can understand". This 
should be the very first hint that Mr. Bratton is completely full of shit. 
What does he even mean by "a journalist who recycles fake insights"? Are 
they recycled because Gladwell didn't conduct the experiments himself? How 
are the insights 'fake'. Let's go on. Maybe Mr. Bratton will explain why he 
resorts to petty name-calling hidden behind flowery language...

"This is not popularization. This is taking something with substance and 
value and coring it out so that it can be swallowed without chewing."

That's just a flowery, cynical description of paraphrasing. Apparently Mr. 
Bratton thinks paraphrasing will bring about the downfall of civilization. 
Let's hear him explain why.

"TED is a proposition. One that says, 'if we talk about world changing 
ideas enough then the world will change'"

Wow. I thought this guy was against paraphrasing and 'oversimplification'. 
Apparently when it serves the purpose of building a shitty straw man, it's 
OK. I thought he was OK with the goal of letting experts share their ideas 
with the public, but now it sounds like doing so could end all of 
Civilization. I'm still unclear on how that works, so let's listen on.

"TED stands for Technology, Entertainment, and Design. To me, TED stands 
for middle-brow, mega-church, infotainment."

More petty name-calling wrapped in hyperbolically cynical language.

"The key rhetorical device of any TED talk is a combination of epiphany and 
personal testimony."

I can think of dozens of TED talks that don't follow this stereotype (or is 
it an 'oversimplification'), however, if you're going to explain an idea to 
people, it often helps to relate how you arrived at said idea which often 
reads as personal testimony leading to epiphany. So what's wrong with that?

"What does the TED audience hope to get from this. A vicarious insight. A 
fleeting moment of wonder. A sense that it's all going to work out after 
all. A spiritual buzz."

Here is the set-up to his main argument. A wonderful stereotype of the TED 
audience as a gaggle mindless dullards. Another straw man. Apparently the 
TED audience isn't made up of individuals with their own reasons for 
watching TED talks. He's enumerated all the possible reasons. I must just 
watch TED for the spiritual buzz it gives me. Right. What's his evidence 
for this so far? He once heard an idiot mention Malcolm Gladwell.

"Well I'm sorry, but that's not up to the challenge of the problems that we 
are ostensibly here to face. Their complex and difficult and not given to 
tidy, just-so solutions. "

OK. So the goal of 'facilitating the spread of ideas in hopes of bringing 
about change in the world' has now become 'solve all of the world's 
problems' and Mr. Bratton is upset because TED is not enough to solve all 
the world's problems. Is his complaint "TED is horrible because it won't 
fix the world"?

"[the world's problems] are complex and difficult and not given to tidy, 
just-so solutions. They don't care about anyone's experience of optimism."

Ah, so the real problem goes back to the dummy audience who apparently is 
just in it for the high and doesn't realize there's more to solving 
problems than just talking about solutions. Stupid audience. What a bunch 
of dummies.

"Given the stakes, having our best and brightest waste their time and the 
audiences time dancing about like infomercial hosts is too high a price. 
And it's cynical"

Sharing ideas in a paraphrased manner is a huge waste of time? Apparently 
if I go to someone with an interesting idea and say, "do you want to share 
your thoughts in a concise talk." I'm actually asking them to dance about 
like an infomercial host. Mr. Bratton laughably uses the word 'cynical' to 
describe such an act while he himself apparently loves hyperbolic cynicism.

"Plus it just doesn't work. [tangent about TED discouraging science-woo]. 
The corollary to placebo science and medicine is placebo politics and 
placebo innovation, and on this count TED has a ways to go. [gives Konny 
2012 as an example]. You see, when inspiration becomes manipulation, 
inspiration becomes obfuscation. And if you're not cynical, you should be 
skeptical."

This is not an example of TED not working. This is an example of why people 
should approach new information with skepticism, because TED, like all 
other forums of discussion, is not perfect. So, the real take away of the 
Konny 2012 anecdote is not that TED is fundamentally harmful to society, 
but that accepting information without critical thinking is a bad idea. 
That has nothing to do with TED. The only way Mr. Bratton has so far tied 
that lesson to TED is by building a straw man of both TED and the TED 
audience.

"Technology: We're told that not only is change accelerating, but the pace 
of change is accelerating. In terms of the computational capacity, this is 
true. But at the same time, (and in-fact the two are related) we're at a 
moment of cultural deceleration. We invest our energies in futuristic 
information technology including our cars, yet we drive them home kitch 
architecture copied from the 18th century.

The future on offer is one in-which everything can change as long as 
everything stays the same. We'll have google glass but we'll still have 
business casual. 
 
This timidity is not our path to the future. This is incredibly 
conservative and more gigaflops will not inoculate us because if a problem 
is endemic to the system then the exponential effects of moors law also 
amplify the problems. It's more computation along the wrong curve."

No single person or even group of people can offer what Mr. Bratton demands 
of Technology-oriented TED talks. A complete vision of the future including 
all of the social, artistic, and technological changes in one cohesive 
view. Is it surprising that one person talks about the single aspect of 
technology that they are focused on and another talks about the work that 
they are doing without also talking about how 'business casual' and 
architecture will change. There's a reason society follows the 'timid' 
trajectory and it's endemic to our limitations as a species. Our inability 
to track every social, political, and technological implication of every 
possible change in trajectory. Moors law is featured in some tech-oriented 
TED talks, but there are plenty that don't. There are plenty that talk 
about changes in architecture and society that must take place.

I'm bored analyzing this shitty talk. He's mad at TED for not being 
something it never purports to be and for his stereotype of the audience 
being so stereotypical.
comments.author: Abe Dillon

comments.text:
+Truthen Tolden
He is scathing in his criticism, sure, but also acknowledges that TED has 
good things to offer too. I think TED (and TED(x) should be able to be 
looked at with a critical eye, and I think Benjamin Bratton was spot on 
with many of his points. People pay a lot of money to attend / support TED, 
and deserve a lot of value from the non-profit.

Many presenters don't do it, but perhaps they could refer people to URLs 
etc. to more detailed items that they cover during their talks, and add 
value to what they are saying during their brief lectures. Often TED just 
comes across for many as an ego-boosting opportunity of narcissistic 
proportions, and does deliver the Reader's Digest version of science to 
many, which you could pick up in 5 minutes watching a PBS special or 
similar. This is where TED falls down a bit.

You can attend a Maker-space for example, or a private user/interest-group, 
and get very similar talks for free. That has been happening since forever. 
TED needs to refine the quality of the presentations a bit, and add value, 
I think that is all that he is asking for here. Most of all, TED should not 
be above critical discussion, and acknowleged for what it does and does not 
deliver to a mass-audience.

goes, TED is pretty limited, but so is pretty much everything humanity has 
ever tried. I've yet to see humanity as a whole solve a complicated, 
morally ambiguous problem at all. I would love to see an example of a high 
level problem involving agreements between government and the private

top_comment.text:
A beautiful deconstruction of the nonsensical idea that talking 
dramatically in an inspirational manner is a way to address large-scale 
challenges.

Many people, understandably, wish to be a critical actor in a Big Change. 
Few possess the ability and determination it takes, but most can either 
manage to talk the talk or fall in rapture with those who can talk the 
talk, and thereby grant themselves the feeling of having the ability and 
determination. Given that this does not create actual Big Change, it is 
best categorized as self-delusion.

The real problem is what the speaker points out early in the presentation: 
this ineffective approach makes it harder for those who are 
productively engaged in discovery and problem solving: they get measured 
not by actual results but by how well they match up to the entirely bogus 
expectations of inspirational presentation skills.

It is one thing for society to conserve the status quo and, as a 
by-product, create friction for the innovator (this is arguably quite a 
good thing as it creates selective pressure on innovation while holding on 
to that which is already proven to work to some acceptable degree) but it 
is entirely another thing for society to attack the founts of progress by 
erecting false idols of intellect in their place.

It may be less personally glamorous, but it is far more useful and 
personally effective to support the true innovators and profound thinkers 
in their arduous and difficult tasks than to pretend the mantle of 
innovation with one's own hollow rhetoric.﻿
top_comment.author: Aaron Seigo

comments.text:

done, but we can outshine them by evolving past the "One (wo)man Show 
Inspiring monologue" format for challenging the status quo.

comments.text:
Furthermore, your charge that we could talk about reducing the poverty gap 
by eliminating money is by all accounts a lazy answer to further your 
argument. You and I both know there are workable solutions to reducing the 
*growing* poverty gap worldwide that don't include the extermination of 
currency. In fact, complementary (not complimentary; don't assume I mean 
free) are a workable solution that has worked in Switzerland for the last 
40 years. They have a currency or line of credit that is only usable 
between businesses called the Wir. Frequent Flyer Miles are essentially a 
complementary currency that has been highly successful in the United States 
in changing consumer behavior and encouraging loyalty to a specific brand, 
so clearly there are more imaginable implements to which this concept could 
be applied. There could be a whole series of talks on money and how to 
reconceptualize it.

Hence the speakers mention that we need to stop falsely dividing the 
economic options between capitalism and collectivism/communalism.

The ground that your argument stands on is steadily shrinking, my friend.

This is clearly not debate of concept but rather an argument about

myself, and Im sure at least a few others who are bothering to read this a 
bit disproportional in the face of the vice of sometimes being "too wordy".

I understood the messages both OP and the Speaker were transmitting. I'm

has not appointed you to be its mouthpiece in the fight to demand "the

this speaker necessarily pander his message (which *is* intellectually 
responsible) if it meant watering down the content? What if what you're 
hearing is the way this man speaks?

comments.text:
"Were discussing the worth about discussing issues."

You may be; I'm not. I firmly believe in democratic discourse and other 
means of information dissemination. I have no problem with discussing 
issues; in fact I'm a huge supporter of that.

TED, however, is not a discussion. It is a presentation platform and it is 
used in a very particular manner that hasn't produced results.

Not all forms of communication are discussion, and not all communication is 
equally useful or impactful.

"See again this statement make it sound like i can go out and grab a shovel 
and start digging for social change."

If you were digging water wells for people who need it, yes , you could 
just grab a shovel and start digging for social change.

"How does one "work" for positive social change?"

Numerous ways, all of which take effort and real engagement.

We could look at the history of revolution to see what it takes on the "big 
and fast" scale.

We could look at the history of technological advancement and how 
technology is employed by people to create positive social change. (Random 
example: the printing press and its evolving uses in the centuries after 
its invention)

We could look at community organization, at entrepreneurship, creation of 
social programs .. all sorts of avenues, and all of which take actual 
effort and usually show some measurable results (one way or the other) 
 within decades. (TED has had 30 years.)

So yes, you can indeed work for positive social change.

You seem to believe that social change happens by people thinking 
differently and then .. society changes. In those two dots ("..") there is 
work, effort, failure and success. The question is whether those two dots 
get done or if communication simply stops with communication. Granted, a 
lot of the time the two dots are ignored: we have erected the mythology of 
"great stirring leadership moment and then amazing thing was accomplished".

It's like how people point to JFK's moon challenge speech and then to the 
moon landing. The moon landing was the result of something that happened 
long before JFK utilized that effort for political gain and occurred 
because people *worked* for it. \

But let's assume that JFK's speech helped make the space program possible 
and all the good things it has since brought society, including getting 
people to dream bigger. That means his speech moved people to accomplish a 
moon landing in 8 years, which in turn inspired millions more. Impressive, 
right? 

Why doesn't TED have anything similar in effect?

"Well written, but not really saying anything."

What you are suffering is cognitive dissonance: I demonstrate how your 
position is ego-centric, you don't see yourself as being that way and so .. 
instead of considering the possibilities .. you dismiss me as a 
grammar-nazi who isn't saying anything. Oy vey.

Look, selflessness is one of the hardest things to achieve. I'm not there 
yet myself, and I wonder if I will ever fully reach it. As people we tend 
to put ourselves into the middle of everything, particularly the universe 
;) It's just a human thing to do. Denying it when it happens traps us 
within that mode of being. Acknowledging it when we see it in the mirror 
held up for us can lead us away from that way of being.

I'm sure that wasn't inspiring in the least, but if you actually hold on to 
that idea and try it out I bet you'll get more from it than all the TED 
talks you've watched combined.

comments.text:
+Fatstogey "hes burdening TED with some sort of need to prove worth"

Actually, TED claims that itself. I already quoted from their About page 
where they make a positive claim about creating change. It is fair to hold 
someone to their own claims.

"TED has inspired me to think of other things ive not before"

I'm not saying that TED does not leave people feeling inspired, or helped 
people to think of things they hadn't before. What I'm saying is that TED 
has demonstrated itself to not be a pathway to *positive societal change*.

I've felt truly stirred by various things I've experienced: music, 
paintings, books on history and philosophy ... and there may be connections 
between that and altering my actions in my life. Yet, I don't think that I 
can say that my going to rock concerts (and I've been to some epicly 
wonderful ones) has created positive social change.

Not everything enjoyable or inspiring need do that.

*But* if a rock band were to claim that their concerts intended to create 
positive social change I would consider whether they do or not.

That's all that is happening with TED.

"The speaker and the OP have inspired me nothing. Sounded fancy, but no 
message got through."

So because no message got through to *you*, then ... it's meaningless?

Would you be open to considering that something that doesn't resonate with 
you in the least might also create more positive social change than 
something that didn't?

Put another way: do you believe that only the things that resonate with you 
have value? That only things that resonate with you personally can create 
positive social change?

"No job was done. "

For you, perhaps. For others, I think the fact that this video is making 
the rounds says otherwise. If it makes people think about working to create 
positive social change rather than only speaking grandly or listening to 
grand presentations, would that not be the real measure?

It is amazingly self-important to suggest that only that which resonates 
with one's own self has value, and that how much it resonates with one's 
own self is a solid indicator for how much positive social change it may 
create. It implies you are the bellweather center of the human universe. 
Can you imagine anymore more egotistical than that?

I happily recognize that things that don't speak to me, let alone inspire 
me, may affect change.

And that (creating social change) is exactly the topic at hand.

comments.text:
I would definitely argue that its inaccurate to state the speaker is 
expecting some kind of instantaneous social change.

I would argue that one of us is misinterpreting his point. Now, I will take 
for all our sakes the possibility that I'm incredibly unintelligent. With 
that concession out of the way, I will put forth what I said before: not 
that the speaker is opposed to TED, but believes it deserves a kind of 
auditing of purpose. 

And as I said before, I personally am not totally opposed to an 
inspirational angle to TED talks. Its nice. Makes me feel warm and like 
we're all capable of doing good things for each other. 

He's asserting that TED is slightly missing the plot on some the largest 
world issues, issues LIKE: the poverty gap; rape as a weapon of war; the 
growing discrepancy between populations with access to communication 
technologies and those that don't...

And that also not *all* technology is necessary, appropriate, or well 
explored. He has high hopes for TED's purpose. It can still be accessible 
*and* more relevant. As it is in his eyes, and indeed in mine (and indeed, 
as a fan of the conference) TED can seem sort of tone deaf, or at least out 
of touch. It all seems well and good, but a lot of it doesn't seem 
feasible. 

I understand how it works though, because I like you, believe in a kind of 
natural selection of ideas: that those ideas with the most utility and 
truth tend to resonate, and therefore it's always advisable to talk and 
debate about ideas.

Your argument, and I'm more than glad to be wrong about this, seems mostly 
steeped in what seems like a distaste for inaccessible language, from what 
I'm reading, veiled accusations regarding the intelligence of your 
opponents.

Furthermore, I'm failing to see what the argued point is, because though we 
disagree on the subject, the disagreement is nearly negligible and boils 
down to: You think TED is fine just the way it is, we see room for 
improvement.

Why is this worth such vicious opposition?
comments.author: Griffin Smith

top_comment.text:
I find it interesting that even Bratton does not criticize the fundamental 
capitalist structure of TED, in that TED charges thousands of dollars to 
attend their conferences and see these talks in person. I kept waiting for 
him to say that "what's wrong with TED" is that, for one, the information 
is so expensive, it makes the charge of elitism reasonable. Any system that 
is set up to make the profit margin as wide as TED's appears to be is a 
system that is automatically not created "for the people" and therefore, 
lacking egalitarianism, is doomed to failure, since the ideas contained 
within are intended for a very small audience (proportionally speaking). 
Perhaps the *real* reason TED ideas echo in a chamber is that they are not 
freely distributed. If TED wants to enact *real* change in the world, they 
should consider allowing anyone and everyone to attend their conferences. 
You can't enact systemic change if only the top echelon have access to the 
information in question. These 10 minute youtubes and 'free' access on 
their website do not count; systemic change requires more commitment than 
simply plugging in for a few minutes and walking away with one new piece of 
infotainment. ﻿

top_comment.text:
What a ridiculously snarky, arrogant talk. With a sweep of his hand Bratton 
dismisses talks by people like Bill Gates, Sir Kenneth Robinson, the NYC 
transportation commissioner Janette Sadik-Kahn (really interesting, check 
it out), a surgeon who's doing face transplants, etc. as "middlebrow". 
First of all, his premise is wrong. TED doesn't claim to change the world. 
TED's focus is simply "Ideas Worth Spreading". It's then up to each person 
to decide which of those ideas is valuable and if they want to spend time 
working on implementing it. Secondly, most speakers aren't making 
prescriptions for the future; generally they are highly accomplished 
individuals describing what they've already done and what they learned from 
it. His description of a donor who won't give money to an astrophysicist 
because his talk is not enough like Malcolm Gladwell is another straw man; 
the guy didn't say the astrophysicist should have something more like a TED 
talk. (I'm not a Gladwell fan, and most TED talks -- by practitioners -- 
are far more substantive than his journalistic pieces.) It's a big media 
universe, I suggest Bratton look for his highbrow truths elsewhere.﻿

+Cy Porter Your comment perfectly illustrates the problem. Perceiving fake

To put it simply, you don't know the first thing about how the 20s actually 
were. For all you know, the perspective you gained through literature

equivalent of 'Cribs'. Attempting to make qualitative judgements by

The reality is, your 'insight' is nothing but a common example of liberal 
conservatism. That your pseudo-intellectual scope of the world is not your 
own but a third-hand regurgitation of somebody else's experiences that 
happened long before you were born. Ie the facebook highlight reel of 
history. 

The fact is, our society and education system actively reinforces and 
legitimizes a culture of liberal conservatism. As if emulating/copying the 
past successes of others is a surefire path to success. Literature is 
preached through the eyes of Hemingway, architecture on the renaissance, 
politics on ancient Greece, economics from the post-depression era, etc... 
All of it is convergent rhetoric dressed up as creativity.

There will always be a culture of divergent thinkers in our society. People 
who reject the notion that originality is nothing more than the rehashing 
of old ideas. People who spend their everyday lives inventing new ideas and 
seeking a deeper understanding via trial and error.

Sadly, legitimization is currently membership based. You have to have to 
have a PHD before you're allowed to have an original idea in college. Wear 
thick rimmed glasses and have a shaved head to be taken seriously as a 
journalist. Have a strange voice or style to be recognized as a musician.

being wrong and, if so, at what point of your life did that fear manifest?

comments.text:
+Carlos Sacchi

Huge swathes of the work force is now freelance, due to the way that the 
internet is making it far easier for people to work from home, and the way 
it enables employers to sort and index job skills through automated 
systems. Many new jobs have been created that 20 years ago would have 
sounded silly. 

The internet also has created a huge alternative to the normal broadcast 
and print mediums of the past. While becoming a viral hit on youtube is 
hardly a normal occurrence for the average person, the massive media 
centralization that began in the 80s is starting to weaken. Means of 
production for media is now cheaper, and the ability to distribute is also 
cheaper. You're seeing backlash against that in cinema, as movies go 3D and 
gain larger and larger budgets to justify their mainstream value. Even the 
funding process has started to democratize as things like Kickstarter and 
IndieGoGo are finally getting some real traction. The nature of media is 
vastly different from it was in the 90s. (not to mention less flashy things 
like the resurgence in independent zines and online radio shows). 

Just another little addition, outside the First World. Smartphone ownership 
is fairly high in many African countries. Areas which have not received 
many of the normal advances of industrialization have been able to latch on 
to cellphones and use them to access world wide telecommunication networks 
that previously had been cut off from them. That's a big deal in it's own 
way.

Some of these things are good and some are bad. For instance freelance 
gives greater independence, but it also means that employers don't pay 
benefits and it also reduces the leverage that workers have with clients. 
I'm not saying things are "better", but to say that things are the same as 
the 90s is absurd.

comments.text:
+Evan Plaice I see you're not a fan of science.

Unlike philosophy in science it is not the best argument that wins, but the 
best evidence. He put forward a *cough* "hypothesis" in which physical 
constants were variable; he gave the specific example of the speed of 
light. He provided no evidence of such claims, and the speed of light is an 
incredibly well verified constant - as per the evidence of experimental 
demonstration (as referred to earlier as Bohrs equations).

For example, the speed of light is used in the Bohr Model of the atom to 
predict the quantisation of angular momentum: r=Ze^2 /4πε_0 mv^2

Another example is the Planck and De Broglie relation for the prediction of 
a wavefunction via the Schroedinger equation.

It is neither an appeal to authority nor a straw man (glad to see you're 
listening in philosophy class), it is *the* evidence that supports the 
speed of light being 299792458 m/s, exactly the sort of evidence that that 
guys talk neither offered nor considered. I would be thrilled if the guy 
was proved right, it would mean a renaissance of new discovery and the 
complete overhaul of modern physics, and I wouldn't even know where to 
begin: its just a shame that he provided absolutely zero evidence that he 
was.

So the fact is, my 'specialized knowledge about physics is essentially 
worthless outside of the context of physics', but when it actually comes to 
discussing physics and the way the universe works... its pretty damn 
useful. ;)

production, asiatic and feudal ones as well. Capitalism isn't to

production, wage labor and so on. Liberals are against absolute power? 
Liberals have always fought for the absolute power of the bourgeois class 
and capital. And the Communists seek the absolute power of the proletarian 
class, undoubtedly. It's becoming very clear that the choice of the future 
will be the destruction of human civilization or Communism. It will be 
socialism or barbarism.
comments.author: HTCEVOSONGS

comments.text:
HTCEVOSONGS seems to think that it is better to *not* engage in democratic 
discussion. He seems to think that it is better to stay away from those 
forums and instead use other means to gain influence. There is a nuance 
between market economy vs. capitalism. It's in the word. Capitalism is to 
capitalize; that is to try to get absolute power by economical means. Most 
people don't get this, but neither communism or socialism is it's opposite. 
It's liberalism. The reason is simple. Most flavours of liberalism is 
against monopolies and absolute power.
comments.author: kebman

comments.text:
Social democracy and democratic socialism aren't the same thing. Democratic 
socialism stems from Bernstein's evolutionary socialism, which yes, stems 
from "democratic means". Social democracy, as it was after the 1940's, is a 
reformed version of the capitalist states, something that maintains 
capitalism yet consists of large social services and welfare.
comments.author: HTCEVOSONGS

comments.text:
Social democracy or democratic socialism is the implementation of socialism 
through democratic means.

democracy.

captions.text: In our culture, talking about the future

is sometimes a polite way
of saying things about the present
that would otherwise be rude or risky.
But have you ever wondered why

so little of the bright futures promised
in TED talks actually come true?
Is something wrong with the ideas?

Or with the notion of what ideas
can do all by themselves?

I write about the entanglements
of technology and culture,

how technologies make certain 
compositions of certain worlds possible,

how culture in turn structures
the evolution of those technologies.

It's where philosophy
and design intersect.

And so the conceptualization
of possibilities
is something that I take very seriously.

And it's for that reason that I,
and a lot of people,

think that it's time
that we take a step back
and ask some serious questions

about the intellectual viability
of things like TED.

And so, my TED talk is not about
my work, my new book,
the usual spiel,

it's about TED — what it is,
and why it doesn't work.

The first reason is
over-simplification.

Now, to be clear, I have
nothing against the idea

of interesting people who do smart things
explaining their work
in a way that everyone can understand.
But TED goes way beyond that.
Let me tell you a story.

I was recently at a presentation
that a friend of mine, astrophysicist,
was making to a potential donor.

And I thought his talk was lucid,
it was engaging...

And I'm a professor of visual arts
here at UC San Diego.

At the end of the day, I know nothing
about astrophysics.

The donor, however, said,
"I'm going to pass, I'm just not inspired.
You should be more like Malcolm Gladwell."
Now, at this point I kind of lost it.
Can you imagine?

I mean, think about it:
a scientist who creates real knowledge

should be more like a journalist
who recycles fake insights.
This is not popularisation.

This is taking something
with substance and value

and coring it out so that it can be
swallowed without chewing.

This is not how we'll confront
our most frightening problems,

this is one of our most frightening
problems.
And so ...
So, what is TED?
TED is perhaps a proposition,

one that says if we talk about
world-changing ideas enough,
then the world will change.

Well, this is not true either.
And that's the second problem.

TED of course stands for
Technology, Entertainment, Design.

To me, TED stands for:
middlebrow megachurch infotainment.
The key rhetorical device at any TED talk

is a combination of epiphany
and personal testimony.

The speaker shares some personal story
of insight and revelation,
its trials and tribulations.

What does the TED audience
hope to get from this?

A vicarious insight?
A fleeting moment of wonder?

A sense that maybe it's all
going to work out after all?
A spiritual buzz?

Well, I'm sorry, but this is not
up to the challenge of the problems
that we are ostensibly here to face.

They are complex and difficult
and not given to tidy just-so solutions.

They don't care about
anyone's experience of optimism.

And given the stakes,
having our best and brightest

waste their time
— and the audience's time —

dancing about like infomercial hosts
is too high a price.
And it's cynical.
Plus, it just doesn't work.

Recently, TEDGlobal sent out a memo
to TEDx local organisers

telling them to avoid booking speakers
whose work spans the paranormal,

conspiratorial, new age 
"quantum neuroenergy" and so forth
— what is called 'woo'.

They should book speakers whose work 
is imaginative but grounded in reality.

And, to be fair, TEDGlobal
took some heat for this,
so the gesture should be acknowledged.

'NO' to placebo science 
and placebo medicine.

But —the corollary to placebo science
and medicine

is placebo politics
and placebo innovation.

And on this count,
TED has a ways to go.

Perhaps the pinnacle of placebo politics
was presented at TEDxSanDiego
a few years ago.

You're familiar, I assume, with the 
Kony2012 social media campaign?
OK, so, what happened here?
Evangelical surfer bro goes to Africa.

He makes campy video explaining genocide
to the cast of Glee. (Laughter)

The world finds his epiphany to be
shallow to the point of self-delusion.

The complex geopolitics of central Africa
are left undisturbed.
Kony's still there.
The end.

You see, when inspiration becomes 
manipulation,
inspiration becomes obfuscation.

And if you're not cynical,
you should be skeptical.

You should be as skeptical of placebo 
politics as you are of placebo medicine.
So ...
T – E – D.
First, Technology.

We're told that not only is change 
accelerating,

but that the pace of change 
is accelerating.

In terms of the computational carrying-
capacity at a planetary level, it is true.

But at the same time
— and in fact the two are related —

we're also in a moment of
cultural de-acceleration.

We invest our energies in
futuristic information technologies,

including our cars,
but drive them home

to kitsch architecture
copied from the 18th century.

The future on offer is one in which
everything can change,
so long as everything stays the same.

We'll have Google Glass,
but we'll still have business casual.

This timidity is not
our path to the future.
This is incredibly conservative.
And more gigaflops won't inoculate us.

Because, if a problem is
endemic to a system,

then the exponential effects of Moore's 
law also amplify what's broken.

It's more computation
along the wrong curve,

and I hardly think
this is a triumph of Reason.

A lot of my work deals with
deep technocultural shifts,

from the post-humanism
to the post-anthropocene,

but the TED version has too much
faith in technology,

and not enough
commitment to technology.
It's placebo technoradicalism,

toying with risk, so as to
reaffirm the comfortable.

And so our machines get smarter
and we get stupider.

But it doesn't have to be that way.
Both can be much more intelligent.
Another futurism is possible.

A better 'E' in TED might stand for
Economics —

— and yes, imagining and designing,
new systems of valuation,

and exchange of accounting for 
transaction externalities,

of financing coordinated planning, 
and so on.

Because states and markets,
states versus markets,

these are insufficient models,
our thinking is stuck in a Cold War gear.

And worse is when economics
is debated like metaphysics,

as if any real system is just
a bad example of the ideal.

Communism in theory
was an egalitarian utopia.

Actually existing communism
meant ecological devastation,
government spying,
crappy cars, gulags.

Capitalism in theory is
rocket ships,
nanomedicine,
Bono saving Africa. (Laughter)

Actually existing capitalism is
Walmart jobs,
McMansions,
people living in sewers under Las Vegas,
Ryan Seacrest. (Laughter)
Plus ecological devastation,
government spying,
crappy public transportation,
and for-profit prisons.

And yet, the alternatives on offer
range from

basically what we have
plus a little more Hayek,

to what we have
plus a little more Keynes.
Why?

The recent centuries have seen
tremendous advances
in improving the quality of life.

But the paradox is that
the system we have now
— whatever you want to call it —

is in the short term what makes
these new technologies possible,

but in the long term it's also
what suppresses their full flowering.

A new economic architecture
is prerequisite.

Perhaps our designers,
instead of prototyping

the same "change agent for good" projects
over and over again,

and then wondering why they aren't
implemented at scale,

we should acknowledge that design
is not some magic answer.

Design is very important,
but for different reasons.

Getting excited about design is easy
because, like talking about the future,

it's more polite than dealing with
the real white elephants in the room.
Such as phones, drones and genomes.

That's what we do here
in San Diego and La Jolla.

In addition to all of the amazingly 
great things that these technologies do,
they're also the basis of NSA spying,
flying robots killing people,

and the wholesale privatisation
of biological life.
That's also what we do.

So you see, the potential
of these technologies

is both wonderful and horrifying
at the same time,

and so to guide them
towards a good future,

design as "innovation" just
isn't strong enough of an idea by itself.

We need to talk a lot more about design
as "immunisation,"

actively preventing certain "innovations"
that we don't want from happening.
So ...

As for one clear take away,
one magic idea,
I don't really have one.
That's kind of the point. (Laughter)
Perhaps I might venture that

if our species were actually to solve
its most dire problems,

perhaps a lot of us in this room
would be out of a job, or perhaps in jail.

It's not as though we don't have a lot
of important things to be talking about.

We need a deeper discussion about
the difference between

digital cosmopolitanism
and cloud feudalism.

And towards that,
a queer history of computer science,
Alan Turing's birthday as a holiday.
I would like new maps of the world,
ones not based on settler colonialism,
legacy genomes,
and bronze age myths,
but something more … scalable.
But TED today is not that.

Our problems are not
"puzzles" to be solved.

This metaphor implies
that all the necessary pieces

are already on the table, just need
to be rearranged and reprogrammed.
It's not true.
"Innovation" defined as "puzzles",

as rearranging pieces
and adding more processing power,

is not some Big Idea that's going to
disrupt the broken status quo —
— that precisely is the broken status quo.

One TED speaker said recently
about his work,

"Now that this boundary is removed,
the only boundary left is our imagination."
Wrong.

If we really want transformation,
we have to slog through the hard stuff —

— the history, economics, philosophy, art,
the ambiguities, and contradictions.

Because focusing just on technology,
or just on innovation,
actually prevents transformation.

We need to raise the level of
general understanding
to the level of complexity of the systems

in which we are embedded
and which are embedded in us.

And this is not about
"personal stories of inspiration".

It's about the hard difficult work of
demystification and reconceptualisation.
More Copernicus, less Tony Robbins.

At a societal level,
the bottom line is that

if we invest in things that make us
feel good but which don't work,

don't invest in things which don't make us
feel good, but which may solve problems,

then our fate is that in the long run
it will just get harder and harder
to feel good about not solving problems.

And in this case, the placebo is not
just ineffective — it's harmful.

Because it takes your interest,
and energy and outrage,

and diverts into this black hole 
of affectation.

"Keep calm and carry on innovating" —
is that the real message of TED?

To me it's not inspirational,
it's cynical.

In the US, the rightwing
has certain media channels
that allow it to bracket reality.
Other constituencies have TED.
Thank you for your time.
(Applause)

title: New Perspectives - What's Wrong with TED Talks? Benjamin Bratton at TEDxSanDiego 2013 - Re:Think
